Over the Labor Day weekend the district will be converting our email addresses from an @acrsd.net format to an @hooscavalley.org format. This is inline with our district name change to Hoosac Valley Regional School District.

For staff this means a format change and domain change so that an email address will be first initial then last name.
(i.e. jon smith would be jsmith@hoosacvalley.org--we used to be formatted as smithj@acrsd.net )

For students we will now have a new domain name and format change. Students will now be formatted as first initial lastname@K12.hoosacvalley.org (i.e. jane smith is jsmith@k12.hoosacvalley.org)

If you had an email address in the old @acrsd.net format that address will still function for incoming mail (i.e. if you are sent an email to your @acrsd.net address it will be received in your new email inbox)

If you have any questions or issues regarding this change you should still use support@acrsd.net to submit a help ticket. Thank you!

IMPORTANT INFORMATION REGARDING P-EBT CARD ACTIVATION

The Massachusetts EBT vendor was not able to change the automated prompts you hear when you call to PIN a card, and unfortunately, some of the automated instructions are inaccurate for P-EBT cards. Instead, please follow the steps below:

Call the EBT card phone number on the back of your P-EBT card: 800-997-2555.
1. Enter your P-EBT card number (it is an 18-digit number).
2. You will then be prompted incorrectly to enter the last four digits of your Social Security number. DO NOT enter the last 4 digits of your Social Security number. For the P-EBT cards, you must enter the last four digits of your child's case number that was provided on the DTA letter you received in the mail.
3. Then enter your child's date of birth using a two-digit month, two-digit day, and four-digit year (example: 04/06/2005).

For more information, visit: https://www.map-ebt.org/. Questions? Call Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline at 800-645-8333.

Hello there-

I am the Director for the Council on Aging in Adams, the Adams Senior Center and we have a request if you'd be so kind to assist. Every weekday we hand out on average 30 Grab n' Go lunches to older adults within our shared communities. Everyday we see several of them smile, frown, wipe back tears and linger longer and longer each day.

We think your beautiful and kind children can help! We're hoping you might get your child, of ANY AGE, to draw a picture with or without a message. If you choose they can sign it with their age. Then if you could mail that image to the Adams COA at 3 Hoosac Street, Adams MA 01220 we would SO GRATEFULLY appreciate it! We plan to take one image a day, make colored copies and place them into their lunch bags each day.

We hope this will put smiles back on their faces, let them feel the connection to a greater part of the community they have lived in and supported each passing year. We plan to get a supporting turn out so really we only need one picture per child. If or when we need more, we'll reach back out. We appreciate your support.

Celebrating Our Seniors...
Thanks to the many who worked hard to put together today’s senior sendoff! It was an honor to be part of this event and nice to once again see so many smiling faces, despite being socially distanced. I know what we’re going through could not have been envisioned, but I also know after participating in the event today that our community is as strong as ever. To our seniors, I admire your resilience and resolve to get through these last 11 weeks. It is difficult to remain focused and motivated with so much going on in the world around you. Despite the challenges, you made it to the finish line! You should be proud of accomplishing this milestone in your life and please know that we are all VERY proud of you. Congratulations! I look forward to celebrating this with you all on July 28th. In the meantime, enjoy the moment and stay safe! #hoosacstrong

Happy New Year!!
On Wednesday the 19th, the HVHS Outing Club did a Solstice Hike/Thunderbolt Cafe on Mt Greylock with Mr. Koamaya and Mr. Lemeiux.

Seth, John, Aiden, and Erica hiked up the Bellows Pipe Trail from the Glenn to the 4 Corners where they stopped for hot chocolate provided by Mr. Lemeiux, who taught them how to use two types of lightweight backpacking stoves. The larger pot is on a stove that twists onto a small fuel canister and lights right up. The smaller pot is with an ultralight canister stove that uses denatured alcohol. He showed them a cheap alternate fuel source of Heet, a gas treatment to remove water.

Keep your eyes out for the next outing, coming in January!!!

This year in Introduction to Timber Framing we had the great pleasure of welcoming one of the most well known timber framing experts in the country into our classroom and shop. Jack Sobon teaches and lectures on the national and international circuit and just got back from 2 weeks in Sweden. This year Jack came to Hoosac for 6 sessions in the classroom and the workshop to share his extensive knowledge and to pass on his love of timber framing to our students. He literally "wrote the book" about timber framing that we use in our class and donated several other books he also authored for future classes. A great guy, Jack is also an Adams native and a Hoosac alum.

post_text: Hoosac Valley Elementary School has decided to join the many other schools across the nation and participate in the “ One Million Acts of Good” that Ellen DeGeneres started to help spread kindness. The Preschool classes of Adams-Cheshire Regional School District have decided to thank our local heroes by creating “energy bags” and dropping them off at the police department in honor of police appreciation day on Tuesday May 15th. The families of our students helped to collect items such as: gatorade, power bars, gum, tactics, chapstick, notepads, pens, tissues, trail mix and hand sanitizer. The students took the time to label each bag with the officers name and attached a note of appreciation. We surprised the officers on duty in Adams by walking to the station and singing, “The More We get together”. A Cheshire officer was invited to the school to gather their goodies. We hope that our youngest students can inspire others to spread kindness. #GoodGoesRound

The families of our students helped to collect items such as: gatorade, power bars, gum, tactics, chapstick, notepads, pens, tissues, trail mix and hand sanitizer. The students took the time to label each bag with the officers name and attached a note of appreciation. We surprised the officers on duty in Adams by walking to the station and singing, “The More We get together”. A Cheshire officer was invited to the school to gather their goodies. We hope that our youngest students can inspire others to spread kindness. #GoodGoesRound

Elementary School Study Buddies:

All 5 kindergarten classes have teamed up with 5 third grade classes in order to provide the kindergarteners with mentors. The K and 3rd grade students will be working on reading, writing,technology, crafts and even play in order to allow for opportunities to grow in all of these areas.
Students must maintain good work and play habits in order to meet with their Study Buddy on a regular basis.
All students are enjoying the program and we have already seen many benefits in both age groups. The program promotes community, self esteem and social awareness.
